newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkey plans 300,000-tonne sugar exports in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Turkey plans 300,000-tonne sugar exports in 1997.

text.p: Turkey's state sugar refinery company Turkseker is planning to export 300,000 tonnes of sugar in calendar 1997, mostly to Azerbaijan, Georgia and Uzbekistan, a senior sugar official said on Friday.
"We will most likely have a surplus in stocks. We are slating 300,000 tonnes of them for exports," the official, who declined to be named, told Reuters.
"We are considering the countries of Azerbaijan, Georgia, Uzbekistan, depending on the demand from them," he said.

He said the timing of the exports would be determined by the world prices. He said Turkey's expected total sugar output of about 1.85 million tonnes in 1996/97, up from 1.5 million a year ago, would enable Turkseker to export.

Turkish officials said earlier in the day Turkseker had offered to sell Iraq 50,000 tonnes of sugar under the U.N. oil-for-food deal which allows Baghdad to sell oil worth $2 billion over six months to buy food and medicine.
The sugar official said Turkseker could also use output from its Carsamba refinery on the Black Sea which it turned into a raws-to-whites processor last year.
"If the buyers need more sugar we can sell the production from Carsamba refinery, but currently there is no such plan," he said.

Turkey imported about 100,000 tonnes of raws earlier this year to process into whites at Carsamba. It exported 12,500 tonnes of the output from Carsamba through a tender in June and holds the remaining output in stocks. --Ercan Ersoy, Ankara Newsroom, 90-312-4462940 REUTER ERC
